passages.text: I celebrate myself, and sing myself, and what I assume you shall assume, for every atom belonging to me as good belongs to you.
passages.context: Opening declaration that the self is universal

passages.text: Do I contradict myself? Very well then I contradict myself. I am large, I contain multitudes.
passages.context: Embracing inner contradictions as a sign of wholeness

passages.text: I believe a leaf of grass is no less than the journey-work of the stars.
passages.context: Finding cosmic significance in the smallest things

passages.text: I exist as I am, that is enough. If no other in the world be aware I sit content, and if each and all be aware I sit content.
passages.context: Radical acceptance of one's own existence

passages.text: The past and present wilt—I have fill'd them, emptied them, and proceed to fill my next fold of the future.
passages.context: The self as an ongoing creative process

passages.text: I am the poet of the Body and I am the poet of the Soul. The pleasures of heaven are with me and the pains of hell are with me.
passages.context: Refusing to separate flesh from spirit

passages.text: I think I could turn and live with animals, they are so placid and self-contain'd. They do not sweat and whine about their condition.
passages.context: Admiring the untroubled presence of animals

passages.text: Re-examine all you have been told at school or church or in any book, dismiss whatever insults your own soul.
passages.context: The soul as final arbiter of truth

passages.text: I sound my barbaric yawp over the roofs of the world.
passages.context: Unapologetic self-expression

passages.text: Afoot and light-hearted I take to the open road, healthy, free, the world before me, the long brown path before me leading wherever I choose.
passages.context: The open road as symbol of infinite possibility

passages.text: I am not contain'd between my hat and boots.
passages.context: The self exceeds the physical form

passages.text: The smallest sprout shows there is really no death, and if ever there was it led forward life.
passages.context: Death as transition rather than ending

passages.text: I hear and behold God in every object, yet understand God not in the least.
passages.context: Divine presence everywhere, comprehension nowhere

passages.text: All truths wait in all things. They neither hasten their own delivery nor resist it.
passages.context: Truth is already present, waiting to be seen

passages.text: I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love. If you want me again look for me under your boot-soles.
passages.context: Final lines—the poet becomes the grass

passages.text: Whoever you are, now I place my hand upon you, that you be my poem. I whisper with my lips close to your ear, I have loved many women and men, but I love none better than you.
passages.context: Direct address that collapses the distance between poet and reader

passages.text: I am he that walks with the tender and growing night. I call to the earth and sea half-held by the night.
passages.context: Erotic relationship with the night itself

passages.text: Have you reckon'd a thousand acres much? Have you reckon'd the earth much? Have you practis'd so long to learn to read? Have you felt so proud to get at the meaning of poems?
passages.context: Challenging the reader's sense of accomplishment

passages.text: Not I, not any one else can travel that road for you. You must travel it for yourself.
passages.context: The irreducible solitude of the spiritual journey

passages.text: Keep your face always toward the sunshine—and shadows will fall behind you.
passages.context: Simple wisdom about where to direct attention
